Text_Numeracy: During my internship at the University of Kansas Medical Center as a Cardiovascular Technologist, I was responsible for monitoring patients as they underwent a treadmill stress test. After the test was concluded, I informed the supervising physician of my observation and the physician requested an echocardiogram to be performed on this patient.

Text_Numeracy: One significant experience that showcased my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I had to manage my own medication regimen. After being prescribed various prescription drugs, I took the initiative to research each one thoroughly, understanding their side effects, potential interactions, and the importance of sticking to my schedule. I also educated myself on the importance of physical activity in maintaining my overall health, which ultimately led me to create a balanced routine that incorporated ample exercise to counterbalance the effects of the medications. This proactive approach not only enhanced my understanding of my own health but also equipped me to discuss any concerns with my psychologist more effectively.
Text_Anxiety: I wouldn't say I feel anxiety per se, but there's definitely a sense of uncertainty whenever I meet with doctors. My main concern tends to be about what they might find or how they will respond to my health history, especially given that I take multiple prescription drugs. I sometimes worry that they might judge my lifestyle choices or question my physical activity routine. Overall, while I try to remain calm and stable, there’s always that underlying tension about the possibility of receiving news that may disrupt my sense of well-being.
Text_TrustPhys: I don't have a primary care physician, so I have mixed feelings about doctors in general. On one hand, I appreciate their expertise and the guidance they can provide, especially when navigating prescription medications and managing my health. However, I sometimes feel that doctors can be a bit distant or overly clinical, which makes it hard for me to fully trust them with my concerns. It can be challenging to find one who truly understands my unique situation and engages with me on a personal level. Overall, I value their knowledge but often feel like there's a gap in communication and understanding.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel that I have a good capacity to obtain and process basic health information, especially given my regular engagement with healthcare professionals and my active lifestyle. While I may not have a primary care physician, I have a routine of visiting specialists and taking prescription medications, which keeps me informed about my health needs. However, I sometimes find it challenging to fully understand all the details of my treatments and prescriptions, especially if they're not clearly explained. Overall, I believe I can make appropriate health decisions, but there's always room for improvement in comprehending complex health information.

Text_Numeracy: In high school, my sister and I went to a college basketball game and someone in the crowd near us collapsed. My sister yelled "Someone call 911!" and the whole crowd froze not knowing what to do. I instantly jumped up and told someone to go call 911 and I sent a few people to get chairs while I cleared away anything near us. I quickly checked if the person's airway was blocked and propped them up so they could breathe (they were still semi-conscious). The ambulance arrived a few minutes later. They said that a blood clot had caused her to faint and if she had been any less fortunate she would have died.

Text_Numeracy: A significant experience that showcased my knowledge of health issues was when I started noticing how my prescription medications were affecting my physical activity levels. This knowledge empowered me to take a more proactive approach in navigating my health and well-being.

Also, with my active lifestyle and various medications, I want to ensure that any doctor I see understands and respects my unique needs, which hasn't always been the case in my experiences.

Text_Numeracy: I was 26 years old when I experienced my first collapse in the Xian unit. The combat brigade doctor who examined me said , "Your body is like a racing car but the driver is a little tired." So I was sent to the horse riding club for a long holiday. After a month of relaxing at the horse riding club, I returned to the Xian unit, but I never fully recovered. A month later, my arms began to bulge and the whole body slowly twisted. I went to the doctor, I was told that my nerves had been pressed out by the vertebrae. After treatment, a week later, the doctor told me to eat and sleep well, that is, to see more subjects more beautiful and reasonably. Because you are now 32 years old and look only 19 years old. As trained professionals, we take enough vitamins and protein every day because our work are intense and need physical energy.

Text_Numeracy: Last year, I had a family member who was going through some health issues. She has always been very healthy and very active. She is mid-60s, and she looked too good for her age. She was sent to a cardiologist, because her primary doctor heard a murmur. The cardio doctor said she had this problem her whole life, and it was not serious. The cardio doctor recommended some tests to make sure there was not a problem with her arteries. She did a sonogram and a heart catheterization. The heart catheterization is where they insert a dye to check for arteries in the heart. The good news was that the arteries were clear, which meant the murmur did not come from any blockage.
Text_Anxiety: I definitely always feel some underlying fear and anxiety when I visit the doctor. Sometimes I'm afraid a medical problem that I'm not aware of will be discovered and that things won't turn out well.

Text_Numeracy: A few months ago, I was dealing with a series of side effects from the various prescription drugs I take regularly. During this time, I took the initiative to research each medication and consulted multiple online resources to better understand their effects and interactions. This knowledge helped me identify a pattern, allowing me to recognize which medication was causing a specific issue. I communicated these findings with a psychologist I frequently visit, even though I don’t have a primary care physician. This experience reinforced my belief in the importance of being informed about my health and the medications I take, as it ultimately led to a more tailored approach to my treatment.
Text_Anxiety: I wouldn’t say I feel overt anxiety when I meet doctors, but there’s definitely a sense of unease. I can feel a bit overwhelmed with the thought of the endless questions about my physical and mental health, especially since I take multiple prescriptions. I sometimes worry they might not fully understand my unique experience or lifestyle, which makes me feel vulnerable. Overall, it's more of a discomfort than full-blown anxiety, really.

My emotional stability helps me approach these situations calmly, but I acknowledge there’s room for improvement in my health literacy.

It has been three years since my operation and I still go for check ups every three months.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that stands out was when I was navigating the complexities of managing my prescription medications. It highlighted for me the importance of being proactive and knowledgeable about health issues, even without a primary care physician to guide me directly.

Text_Numeracy: A few years ago, I went on a ski trip with my friends. One day while I was snowboarding, I took an awkward fall and ended up dislocating my right shoulder. While I was waiting for the ski patrol to come help me, I remembered that I had taken a signal anatomy and physiology course less than a year before the trip. Because of the knowledge I gained in that class, I was able to differentiate between the types of shoulder dislocations and determine that I had a subcoracoid dislocation. Once I was at the hospital, the doctors were very impressed that I was able to self diagnose my injury and ended up giving me more treatment options because I had a better understanding of how the body works.

Text_Numeracy: Seven years ago, my immune system was impaired due to long-term meathotrexate (a form of chemotheraphy) treatment. During that time, I was hospitalized for 4 days and placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to kidney infection. After I was released, I was put on a prolonged regimen of antibiotic. After one month, I developed flooding diarrhea. Concerned about potential antibiotic-acquired colitis, I called the urgi-care to get an appointment to see the physician. To my surprise, when I arrived at Urgi-Care, I was still assigned to the same physician who was involved in my previous claims from the past two months. Without going through with any type of examination, my physician said that I was experiencing flu-like symptoms and attitude that my concerns were invalid. I insisted that she perform diagnostic testing for colitis, which is normally diagnostic a different facility. My insistence paid off. I tested positive for c-diff.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that really highlighted my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I started managing my prescription medications. I was on multiple drugs for various reasons, and I took it upon myself to research each medication's effects, potential interactions, and what signs to watch for regarding side effects. This self-education became crucial when I noticed a change in how I felt physically; I recognized that my energy levels were dipping and that might be related to one of the new prescriptions. Discussing this with my psychologist helped me advocate for my health and prompted me to finally seek a primary care physician who could oversee my medication regimen more effectively.
Text_Anxiety: I wouldn't say I feel anxiety per se when meeting doctors, but I do get a sense of apprehension about the uncertainty of what they might say regarding my prescriptions or the need for adjustments. Sometimes I wonder if they will scrutinize my medication use or question my lifestyle choices, even though I know I engage in many physical activities. I guess I'm just caught in this space of wanting to present my best self while navigating their expectations and judgments, which can feel a bit overwhelming. Overall, I just focus on being open and honest during my visits to keep the conversation flowing positively.
Text_TrustPhys: Since I don't have a primary care physician, my experience with doctors in general has been quite varied. I tend to trust those who take the time to listen to my concerns and consider my unique lifestyle, especially since I'm on multiple prescription drugs and very active. However, I sometimes feel a distrust towards doctors who seem rushed or dismissive, as it makes me question whether they're truly understanding my needs. My frequent visits to different doctors mean I often feel like I'm starting from scratch each time, which adds to my uncertainty about building a reliable rapport with any single physician.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel quite confident in my capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. My frequent visits to various healthcare providers and my engagement with different prescription medications have made me more knowledgeable about health topics and the medical system. I actively seek out information and do my best to stay informed about my health, which helps me make appropriate decisions. However, I also recognize that there might be complexities in understanding all aspects of my health, especially with the number of prescriptions I take. Despite this, I believe my enthusiasm and openness to experiences drive me to explore and learn more about my health when needed.
